√âtant un fan inconditionnel de la s√©rie Animal Crossing, je ne peux qu'√™tre d√©sesp√©r√© √† l'id√©e de voir le tournant que la s√©rie a pris.J'ai √©t√© tr√®s heureux durant le tout premier trailer en 2019 et au final, j'en ressors tr√®s d√©√ßu.J'ai eu le jeu le 20 Mars, j'y ai jou√© jusqu'√† d√©but Mai pour au final, ne plus jamais le relancer... Et √ßa m'a fait un bien fou de ne plus le relancer.Points positifs :‚Ä¢ Graphiquement, le jeu est magnifique. C'est parfait.‚Ä¢ Le terraforming‚Ä¢ La d√©coration de l'√Æle‚Ä¢ Les recettes de craft‚Ä¢ De nombreux v√™tements‚Ä¢ Les petits d√©tails mat√©riels apport√©s aux habitants qui paraissent plus vivants, mais aussi √† l'√Æle tel que le vent venant balay√© les feuilles ou encore les gouttelettes de pluie ruisselant sur les feuilles.Points n√©gatifs :‚Ä¢ Un des √©l√©ments principal du jeu : le craft. L√† o√π le craft aurait d√ª √™tre le gros point fort du jeu, on se retrouve finalement avec un syst√®me de craft tr√®s d√©pass√©, qui n'a m√™me jamais exist√© dans un jeu vid√©o tant il est peu ergonomique et nous pousse √† marteler le bouton A afin d'essayer d'aller plus vite. Impossible de crafter plusieurs objets √† la fois, impossible d'avoir acc√®s √† notre stock depuis l'√©tabli... Le joueur est forc√© de tout faire un par un, c'est inadmissible.‚Ä¢ Le terraforming, je le mets aussi en point n√©gatif car il est tr√®s mal foutu. C'est de l'approximation √† l'√©tat pur car il est impossible d'√™tre pr√©cis en se d√©pla√ßant au stick et avec la pelle. Ils auraient d√ª implanter un syst√®me de map en vue du dessus, case par case, permettant une refonte propre et pr√©cise. Les motifs ne peuvent pas se coller aux bordures des rivi√®res/√©tangs/ponts donc le joueur se retrouve forc√©ment avec des lignes d'herbes bien d√©gueulasse qui cassent tout.‚Ä¢ Par rapport √† New Leaf, le catalogue des meubles a perdu plus de 500 objets, dont des s√©ries de meubles tr√®s populaires. Adieu la s√©rie royale, rococo, nintendo, n√©glig√©e, minimaliste, rayure, nordique et j'en passe. C'est une r√©gression inadmissible, surtout quand un jeu 3DS fait mieux qu'un jeu Switch √† ce niveau... Sans oublier que New Horizons s'est volontairement dirig√© vers un jeu m√™lant d√©coration de l'√Æle et craft. √Ä quoi √ßa sert si plus de 500 meubles ont √©t√© retir√©s du jeu ?‚Ä¢ En parlant de d√©coration, la maison du joueur a aussi vu sa taille r√©tr√©cir puisque dans New Horizons, le joueur poss√®de une pi√®ce principale en 8x8, trois pi√®ces adjacentes en 6x6 et 2 pi√®ces aux √©tages en 6x10. Sur les anciens opus, les pi√®ces de la maison √©taient toutes en 8x8. C'est donc une perte de 92 cases (si j'ai bien compt√©), comme s'il y avait environ une pi√®ce et demi en moins dans la maison. C'est inexcusable.‚Ä¢ Les dialogues des habitants se r√©p√®tent tous, ils n'ont plus aucune personnalit√©. Il suffit de leur parler plusieurs fois par jour pour constater qu'ils disent √† peu pr√®s tous la m√™me chose. D'ailleurs, pourquoi les habitantes arrogantes sont aussi gentilles ?Sans oublier Marie qui est inutile et chiante avec ses annonces √† chaque lancement de la partie, pour nous dire qu'elle a bu du jus de chaussette hier soir.‚Ä¢ La casse des outils est la pire id√©e du monde, c'est affreux de devoir refaire des allers-retours constant afin d'en recrafter/racheter. Les outils en or ne sont m√™me pas incassables, √† quoi servent-ils si ce n'est nous faire d√©penser des p√©pites d'or ?‚Ä¢ L'OST m√©diocre, c'est dur de passer de Wild World et New Leaf √† √ßa.‚Ä¢ Trop de PNJ manquants, trop d'√©v√©nements qui ne servent √† rien et nous poussent simplement √† prendre des photos inutiles, le syst√®me Nook Miles qui devient tr√®s lourd √† force avec un smartphone tr√®s toxique et intrusif (comme dans la vie r√©elle, le comble pour un jeu Animal Crossing), des √Æles myst√®res chiantes, des mini-jeux inexistants, un online vide, d√©sastreux et qui date d'une autre √©poque (impossible d'avoir acc√®s au stock et √† la banque), les recettes de craft qui ne sont pas stockables et reviennent souvent en double, triple, quadruple... Sans oublier le vide du magasin M&M avec les m√™mes meubles qui apparaissent, la cabine d'essayage des SDDF qui nous emp√™chent d'acheter plusieurs hauts ou plusieurs bas √† la fois...Je vais m'arr√™ter l√† car il y a une limite de caract√®res, j'aurai encore beaucoup de critiques √† faire mais l'essentiel est r√©sum√©.Nintendo s'est tourn√© vers une politique du jeu en kit. Peut-√™tre que les futurs mises √† jours effaceront certains d√©fauts et je l'esp√®re mais en l'√©tat, le jeu ne vaut pas plus que la moyenne.

Ce jeu se destine essentiellement aux enfants et jeunes adolescents. Il propose beaucoup d'activit√©s vari√©es et surtout une grande libert√© de choix pour les joueurs.Parmi ces activit√©s, beaucoup d'√©l√©ments sont vraiment int√©ressants pour le public cibl√© : la gestion d'un budget, d'un compte bancaire, la d√©couverte de la faune et de la flore, et m√™me quelques contacts avec des oeuvres d'arts accompagn√©es d'explications sur leurs auteurs et leurs origines. L'id√©e de conduire les enfants √† faire quelques recherches pour d√©terminer si l'oeuvre qui leur ait pr√©sent√©e est authentique est m√™me tr√®s judicieuse √† mon sens. I pre-ordered this a while ago for my Nintendo Switch Lite.I have spent 2 days playing it so far and im not getting to bed until 4am, its so addictive. Good job we all are self isolating because of Coronavirus because i think i would lose my job.Its a nifty little game, there is so much to do, there is lots of going back and forth, gathering materials, making tools, accumulating miles and bells, fishing, and visiting mystery islands.I think ive played a good 20 hours so far over the 2 days, and ive only just managed to pay nook his 5000 miles and took a loan out for my house. There is a lot of work to do.This will take me months and months to get through, i am okay with that though because it keeps me busy, distracted from the isolation, and i really enjoy it.Fantastic value.Update:Im not sure if any you have played this before but wanted to share some tips and tricks that i had to figure out the hard way.You start off with a native fruit, mine was oranges. You have to pay 2000 miles for a nook ticket to visit mystery islands to try and forage iron nuggets and other fruits. Once you have those fruits do not sell them. Use your flimsy shovel to dig holes and then plant the fruit in the holes and it will grow a fuit tree. You have to look for Oranges, Cherries, Pears, Apples, Peaches, and Coconuts. On that last one, Coconut trees can only be planted on the beach.When foraging for iron nuggets, dig 2 holes behind you so that you dont fall backwards, and hit your stones with a shovel and it will spit out iron nuggets. You will need 30 to give to Nook to build the shop.Also fish twice a day, once in the daytime and once at night because you will get different types of fish.Upgrade with your miles to get bigger storage, it will cost you 8000 miles but its worth it.You will need a vaulting pole to jump over rivers. You will get it from Blathers when you give him 15 specimens to open the museum. Unlike other tools it wont ever break.Be prepared to replace your tools a lot because they do not last. When you get your house start stockpiling wood. Your house comes with a nifty feature. Free storage. You press right on the direction pad and you can put things into storage for safe keeping.  Shake your trees every day to get tree branches. Each tree will spit out 8 branches, but never more than that. Same with your fruit. Stockpile. You can use it to trade for other fruits when you visit other islands or when you get online friend codes. And you can use it to plant fruit trees. I have planted hundreds all over my island. Nook also gives you money for fruit so its a good money making scheme.When you get your shovel, once a day you will notice a glowing spot on the ground, use your shovel and dig a hole. It will give you a money bag. 1st one is 1000 bells. Leave the hole open and click x to select the bag but use the joystick to increase the value of the bag to 10,000 bells and then bury the bag in the hole. This gives you a money tree. Each tree then gives you 3 bags of 10,000 bells. You can then use your shovel to dig the money tree up and replant it somewhere easier to find. Ive put all mine next to my house, i have 4 so far.You will need them becuase infastructure later in the game is expensive. Your 1st bridge costs you over 100, 000 bells and more so you need a lot of money.Thats as far as ive got so far. Hope this has been helpful.

This is the best game ever, and thank god for it. I‚Äôm currently on furlough from work due to the Coronavirus, this game has been my life saver and when I have felt anxious or worried it has kept me sane.I have always loved Animal Crossing and played the previous games, but by far this is the best one I find it relaxing, very addictive and saved many an argument over the remote control for the TV.  Its fun for adults and I can imagine for older children it could be educational, such as having to work for money (or in this case Bells and Nook Miles), paying a mortgage off, also finding out about different Critters.  When you donate a new fish/bug or fossil Blathers the wise old Owl from the museum will tell you a little about the item you are donating. Also you can design things, decorate your own house and keep friends with your neighbours,  this is just a selection of the activities included.There is so much involved and so much to do once you have helped build the basics of the island like where you want to live, the Museum, Town Hall, Shops and assisted new residents to move to your island you pretty much free to do what you want.  You have the usual change of seasons, catching bugs, various fish (which change over the year) and finding fossils but a recent update now sees us deep sea diving for various sea creatures.  You still have the usual tournaments and annual events such as Halloween and Easter.What makes this Animal Crossing different is that when you arrive at your chosen island it is deserted and you are limited to where you can go on the island, you have no ladder to climb the cliffs and a vaulting pole to vault across the rivers, so choose wisely, the aesthetics of island does not really matter as you are able to terraform the land later.  As you have no equipment or furniture and no means to buy them as the game progresses you go from flimsy tools to more robust equipment, you also get recipes to build a whole range of furniture and accessoriesYou also have a choice between the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere, and you get the seasons to match.Also we see introduced are Nook Miles which can be earned by performing various tasks, Nook Miles can buy you certain items to decorate your island, terraforming equipment and best of all air miles so you can fly off to other deserted islands, if you are lucky to get a rare island it will bring in some big Bells (money).  You also have the opportunity to pick fruit that is not native to your island and stock up on the essentials to build furniture & equipment.The only downside of this game is that you cannot have multiple Animal Crossing discs on one console, it is one island per console, to have more than one island you would need a Switch console per game, which to me seems wrong.  You can have multiple players for the same island, but if everyone wants to play the game at the same time it could cause friction, lucky for me that is not an issue. Can I recommend it, if your looking for a lovely stress free game that has so much packed into it then go for it, it is worth every penny.

Animal crossing is Mindless and Pointless.Yup I said it. Animal Crossing is both mindless, and pointless.It is a groundhog day of a game. The same things, over and over. Wake up, shake trees, catch wasps, hit rocks, hit trees, speak to villagers, catch tarantulas, avoid that final house expansion debt, decorate your island.It takes no skill, minimal creativity and literally no thought.It‚Äôs perfect.I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve noticed, but there is a global pandemic going on at the moment. People being locked down, confined to their homes, unable to see friends or family. Events postponed or cancelled, trips and visits prohibited.But in the world of animal crossing you have a whole island, with people on it, where you can go where you want, do what you want and see who you want and visit those friends you haven‚Äôt seen in real life for more than a month.Whilst sitting in the same place you always sit to play; you can completely change your surroundings. No need to spend real money, no virtual B&Q queues and no risk of falling off the stepladder and having to go to Casualty.You can go and visit your friends and marvel at their creativity, how they have decorated their home, the different areas of their island and which villagers they have. You can get on a dodo airlines flight and jet set to new unexplored island to harvest materials or to find a rare island for big fish, butterflies or those 8-legged pay checks the tarantulas.There are events, which can be social and give you a sense of purpose for the day, or you can just sit on your mismatched furniture that fell out of a tree and wait for shooting stars.The fact it takes little thought is what is going to get some of us through this difficult time.Real life has worries in it, people losing their jobs, people not getting paid, people worried about finances, businesses closing, families struggling, key workers bearing the brunt of mental burden on the front line, constant news of worries about the NHS, medical burden, DNR orders, PPE, new emergency hospitals. People dying. Vulnerable people worried, suffering, alone and scared.But in my little island I catch an emperor butterfly which gives me enough money to buy a whole new outfit for my little pixel body that doesn‚Äôt change no matter how much ice cream I‚Äôve eaten. I don‚Äôt have to work from home on that island. I don‚Äôt have to wonder whether to wear a mask next time I go to buy milk. My biggest worry is whether I'll get the turnip stock market right this week.Isabelle cheerfully announces that there‚Äôs no news today! A stark contrast to the daily death toll on the real news.Tom Nook checks whether a villager is OK with you uprooting their entire life to move them across the island, they pop in and strangely enough they never mind! In real life if you want to speak to anyone? You‚Äôd better hope you‚Äôre 6 ft way from them.In short, if you want somewhere to live the easy life, where corona virus doesn‚Äôt exist, go find your own new island. Give it a good name, design your own clothing, paintings and decorations and live in a better world with friends all from the comfort of your ice cream stained pyjamas.

So, as an animal crossing fan, when this new game came out, I simply HAD to get it! I purchased it here on Amazon as it was the best price, & was inclusive of speedy free prime delivery, so I could not go wrong. In actual fact, I also purchased a second game as a birthday gift, & had it delivered straight to them, which was great, & they were, & still are, thrilled with this!For those of you who've not played animal crossing before, & for those of you who have, this game is deffo worth buying as it has HOURS & each day of game play! It is timed to real-time, & the real date, & not only does this game change weather, change seasons in accordance to our actual seasons, but it also celebrates all the various festive events throughout the year too, like Halloween, Christmas etc. Each day on the island is different!This game consists of you being a little person, who you can customise, & you set up camp on an island, & its your job to develop the island so that new guests move to the island, & your job to take care of the island & its renovations, which involves having to make ¬£ by various means, - shaking trees, collecting fruit, fishing, catching bugs, digging fossils, & even swimming in the sea! - & more! - all of which are fun activities to do, & you get to see your island develop. Whats more is you get to customise your house, expand your house, change your outfits, & even create your own custom designs for clothing, wallpaper, floor etc, so this game has a creative aspect to it too. This game is just so addictive! You actually look forward to playing on it the next day, as each day progresses through the period of the day just like our own, & no 2 days are the same!I would deffo highly recommend this game, & its not just for kids, as I'm an adult & I know this is a fave game for adults too! Here on Amazon its pretty much always at the best price, if you are shopping around & looking for the best price, & delivery is included too, so its deffo worth its price, & buying on here.I hope this review has been helpful, & don't hesitate to ask if you have any questions, üòâ

The other half was looking forward to this game coming out so much and I honestly had no idea what it was or why he kept mentioning it.  Seeing as we were under lockdown and I am one of those lucky enough to be able to work from home with an employer that is keeping me on I decided to splurge and buy it.BIG MISTAKE!The premise is decidedly straightforward. You move to an island and build up it's infrastructure to get others to move in.  The in game currency is Bells and you earn these by catching bugs and fish and selling them at the local store. No microtransactions to worry about. You Just need to work to earn money and then spend it on home improvements, building properties to encourage people to move in and buy thrall important Book Miles to visit other islands and plunder them for resources.  Charming graphics Bound and it is all incredibly child friendly, although the pubs when you catch anything start wearing thin after a while.The only issue is down to the way the Nintendo Switch works. Got one copy of the game and one console, and two of you that want to play? Well, you only get the one island to share between you. Very frustrating, especially as I had a quick to and was immediately hooked.  So, I had to buy my one Switch to be able to have my own island and the knock on effect of that was buying two copies of the game so that we aren't bickering over who's turn it is to have the game cartridge.Relaxing and incredibly fun to play. You will lose hours of your life playing this game.  I decided to redo my three rooms I purchased for my house and before I knew it I'd spent 2 hours just shifting furniture and don't even get me started on time flying whilst I fish or bug hunt.  Genuinely suitable for all ages and no worries about spending real world.money on in game purchases.

I haven't been obsessed with a video game since Mario on the NES in 1986. I'm now 40 years old and unashamedly hooked.This game is beautiful, achievable, calming and joyous. It's impossible to get it wrong, just many, many ways to get it right. My daughter and I love running around our island, shaking trees, catching fish and chatting to our bizarre range of neighbours. It's the perfect antidote to lockdown.My top tip is to get yourself a wetsuit as quick as you can and get diving. It's by far the quickest way to earn bells. I tend to empty my pockets on the shore so I've got plenty of space, and do a full circumnavigation of the island before selling it all in the shop. The harder they are to catch the more they are worth - king crabs are a challenge but sell for something like 8000 bells each, so be persistent!My other top tip is to expand your pockets as soon as you are able by redeeming miles for the pocket organisation guide at the Nook Stop. It's expensive but makes you far more efficient and means you can get more stuck in without having to keep returning to the shop to sell the contents of your pockets.I have seen some criticism that it's not good for multiple players. It's true that playing at the same time is pretty rubbish - only one of you can be the leader and the other one just has to follow behind looking interested. But if you go in as separate profiles and play at different times the second player can do nearly everything the main player can, including building and upgrading their home, gathering and selling resources, and using the Island Designer app.If you have a Switch, get this game. You won't regret it, although it may eat up all your spare time... Having said that, at the moment we can't go out anyway so there's nothing to lose!

By coincidence, I ordered this in time for it to arrive on the first day of the new lockdown. It's been almost two weeks now and I've played it for at least two hours a day.I play a lot of The Sims so I'm used to a slow pace of game play, and the grind to make money and unlock new items. Admittedly I can spend ages on here collecting wood and making furniture to sell, swimming and hunting for sea creatures to sell, hunting for shells to sell... you get the idea. I seem to unlock something new or meet a new character every couple of days, as well upgrading buildings and so on. I love waking up each day to see what's happened on my island overnight.I find the gameplay so peaceful as well. Not only does the game look so beautiful and appealing, but all the sound effects - from your villagers "talking" to you, to the sound of footsteps and the sea - are so calming and relaxing to me too.The fact that you can connect with friends is a big plus for me too, especially at a time when you can't spend time with your loved ones. My best friend (I'm 31 and she's 30!) recieved a copy for Christmas too, so she's around ten days ahead of me and can give me tips and clues to what's up and coming on my island. I love being able to visit each other's islands in real time, and that we can send each other nice gifts and things we find on our islands. I daresay we'll both put an awful lot more time into our games. :)

I waited for ages for this game to come out and I was so excited for it's release. I've put 200+ hours into the game, and it is enjoyable in parts but it feels like there are some major things missing that could have made it way more fun. There are some great in-game challenges that are enough to keep you engrossed for a short time - getting a 5 star island, upgrading your house, helping build and recruit new islanders, and the events are worth dropping back into the game for.The issue I have is how unsatisfying some of the crafting and multiplayer aspects are. There are a lot of things that could have made this game better. As far as co-operative play goes, there's very little. You can visit or be visited by your friends and you can also gift them 2 items a day. It would have been so much more fun if your guests could interact with your island, or even help craft and decorate the island. Imagine if your friends could donate bugs or fish to your museum? There could have been a whole trading system to help you decorate or fulfil your critter collections. The shop very quickly repeated the same few items, so having some sort of trade post, or a hub where you can meet other gamers to trade would have been amazing.As much as I love the Animal Crossing games, I feel that the mobile phone game Pocket Camp had way more to offer. The islanders on New Horizons are all carbon copies of each other and the interaction with them is poor. I would have loved to see more quests and challenges being given by the island residents.New Horizons is a lot of fun, but I felt like I was waiting for the game to open up and it never did. They are always adding updates (such as the recent swimming update) so I'm sure it's a game I'll hold onto and dip back into in time. It's probably more suited towards a younger audience, as I was just left feeling very unfulfilled. Having played much deeper farming games such as Stardew Valley, I feel that AC New Horizons is just a bare bones experience of similar games.

Animal Crossing New Horizons is one of those strange little oddities that sucks you in and keeps you coming back every day to maintain your crops and get your daily Nook Miles.You can never really put your finger on why you enjoy it. It could easily become a bit of a chore. But it feels so cutesy and charming (although I will admit I got a somewhat sinister feeling from Tom Nook at the beginning of the game - he turned out to be an alright guy though) and it offers such a relaxing experience that the work feels less of a chore and more something you look forward to doing every day.There‚Äôs something really satisfying about building your island from scratch and turning it into your own little town. Even better that you can show it off to your friends and visit their creations with relative ease.The only issue I have with the game is I can only have one island on my Switch, meaning I have to share the island with my daughter which can cause a few headaches as our ideas sometimes clash. It‚Äôs a small niggle though.A ton of fun and highly recommended for anyone that‚Äôs feeling the stresses of the real world and wants to escape somewhere relaxing.
Well received

I got the game to keep my girlfriend happy, it's not as engaging, if you like spending tons of time on trivial tasks and message bubbles collecting hundreds of characters or selling turnips then it's a game for you. Everyone I have spoken to has played the game properly for the first 20-100 hours, after that they start to time-travel, which is kinda a legal cheat, because acquiring things in real-time will take forever, my partner spend about 100-180 hours playing the proper way, the moment she switched she became a millionaire, to me having to time-travel to enjoy the game is not that joyful for me, albeit I take a 25% cut for whatever she earns (mainly for the lols) so I am literally a millionaire with like 20-30 hours game time.The best thing I can say about the game is the community, be it on forums, discords or reddit among platforms, most people are positive, engaged, genuinely nice and helpful. The game lacks proper co-op, you can interact, have some fun, trade items and steal peoples fruit, but you cannot truly help people with their islands, upon completion of the game (not really a spoiler) you get to terraform your island, but you can only do that whilst nobody is on your island, and that takes a hella lot of time. I bought the game for the sake of my partner, which a lot of people are doing to keep them happy, they need to add more co-op features for this reason.The game CAN be fun to play, especially in a discord call with friends, the biggest problem I have with the game is the completion time, without the help of my partner, what I achieved in 20-30 hours would have taken 120 hours or more without time-travel (which I have yet to do) I have friends whom have over 1,000 hours and still haven't completed everything, couple of friends who are nearing 1,500 hours and would be 95% completed, but they spend most of their time time-travelling to find the last 1 or 2 items/characters. I would recommend this game if you have many hundreds or thousands of hours to waste, otherwise just buy a proper single-player game that will give you joy for 20-50 hours play-time.

I bought this as a gift for my partner - I don't own a switch, nor have I played any of the previous Animal Crossings instalments. Therefore, my review will be much of the same. I'm not a completely new convert, nor am I a weathered veteran of the franchise. But I must say, for a very hyped up and much anticipated game, it does look to deliver. It's an almost open-world delve into creating your town, complete with trading, catching animals, establishing museums, interactions and much more. Doubling down on the epic scope of the game's predecessor, this has no doubt days, if not weeks (possibly months) of gametime, and things to do. There does seem to be a story, but there's much more you can do besides that. It's a game you can invest a little in, or a lot in. It matches the real-world time, meaning you must be patient - but not pay - if you wish to get the best experience. The game looks amazing, has a playful humour about it, and appeals to fans of all ages, not just children. Even I admit it does look compelling, and my partner really loves it. They spend almost every day playing it, and - given the current situation - is exactly what they need. It's a vibrant game, and a nice change to the dark, gritty, adult games the market seems swamped with these days. It's expensive, true - it's Nintendo, and a big title, after all - but it seems to deliver and more.

It's Animal Crossing. What more do you really need to know? If you've played and enjoyed the series before, this is probs the most comprehensive version yet, so it's also the best way for newcomers to enter the series. If you don't like the series, this won't change your mind.One thing about New Horizons that even longtime fans could be caught off guard by is the lack of so many features from previous games. This content is getting patched in through updates sure, so this review is inevitably going to be irrelevant, but playing it now, even 4 months after launch, it does not feel like an 100% finished game. Even though the updates are free, people are still going to have to continually pay for online membership to play with friends when the new content comes out, compared to paying for like a three month membership and be done with it. This is going to continue until at least December, seeing as Holidays content is also being added in this manner. Its just a way for players to be forced to keep playing and paying for this game. I know Animal Crossing is meant to have a long shelf life anyway and most people pay for Switch Online Membership irregardless, but it's still a pretty suspect way to reinforce this.So yea, to wrap it all up, you could probably say that this is the best ever and most exhaustive Animal Crossing entry, but you won't be able to say that with absolute certainty for another few months, at the least.

This is my first Animal Crossing game after being quite reluctant to buy it and I've quickly fallen in love with the charm of it. I can see this appealing to a very wide demographic of people and ages who just want a nice, chilled out, moderately paced game.The thing I love mostly about this game is that I can play for an hour or two and be satisfied enough to put it down. Many other games induce me into a state where I feel compelled to play and play and play, whilst that is on one hand a sign of an enjoyable game, it can also be a little bit draining. Perfect especially in the evening when you just want to relax a little bit but not play for so long that you end up going to bed late.Also as someone who really likes learning about fauna, this game steadily is introducing me to a range of new fish, fossils and insects as I continue to alter my island and/or the season changes. All of which you get to view anytime in your own museum once you've discovered it. This game just really is built up on a range of great little details.If you need to clock out of reality for an hour or two a day, by all means get this game.

Sims like game with anthropomorphic animals set on your own desert island with 3 raccoons and 2 NPC. You move in and soon find yourself indebted to Tom nook from Nook inc. Use crafting and build some tools. Collect sea shells and DIY recipes, plant trees, gather branches and realise its been 2 hours. A game of collecting and creating with a simple gameplay loop. Game mirrors real time and seasons so there's always something to do, day or night.This game is a grind, a slow burn. You are encouraged to check in daily as any buildings will be erected over night. Some days there will be nothing you can do but wait, so you spend an hour ordering your house and stealing presents. A light game, nice colours and graphics, cute creatures, great soundtrack and serene sounds - do as much or as little as you want. Make friends and socialise. Enjoy spamming through conversations with NPCs like timmy and tommy and tom coz you are gonna have many.You feel less and less used like a mule for nook inc. the more you progress! Meeting new friends and keeping them happy while your island blooms and grows.Create and borrow online custom designs to get cool and awesome community-made designs. A lot of die hard fans but casuals will be sucked in too. Oh, and free DLC!

the game is so detailed and my family members enjoyed to live virtually in the game!the game keep creating so many missions for you to do, so many ways to play to earn bells, miles and thousands of customisable items to decorate your island, you houseand even i can play with many of my friends, colleagues and i‚Äôm so surprised they are playing too! and some long lost contact friends, now we have much more things to talkbut one very important things to remember, once the game created in a console, you cannot transfer it to another, like my case, i created the game with my switch lite, when one day i want to play the game in a bigger tv screen, it doesn‚Äôt have a game save transfer function (yet), so i can only keep playing it in the same consolealso, make sure don‚Äôt corrupt the game save, don‚Äôt turn off while saving, i saw so many cases that the game save corrupted and you have to start all over again, wasted a few hundred hours effort that made the island look so great!anyway, this is the best game i ever had for my nintendo switch, it‚Äôs better than the all times leading mario kart game now

Absolutely fantastic and exceeds every one of my expectations.Having played the previous games in the series, I knew what to expect and I was pleasantly surprised by the new theme of the game.You and the loveable Tom Nook travel to a decent sized island and make your home there. From this point you are free to do as you wish, collecting bugs, fishing, making new friends. There are tasks you can complete generally Via Tom Nook‚Äôs instruction, to expand your life on the island and soon you will be inviting more guests to live, including amenities such as shops and entertainment.Please be warned, like all previous Animal Crossing games, there is only one save file allowed and though you will be able to play with multiple characters, only the main account has full access to the game.It makes me sad seeing reviewers give such a fantastic and fun game such a low rating for something that has always been a part of the game series.There has never been more than one save file and you have always been able to create multiple characters in the game but with limited features available.Other than that, this is an amazing game and definitely worth all the time and effort you‚Äôll be putting into it!

Would have given it a 5, but my wife was playing this one time and it got rid of all the iron ores she collected. She had 45 and needed 50 to make an object for her house. However, trying to open the game and get the last 5 ores for the object for her house, she was shocked and startled to find most ores had disappeared. Her face said it all as she was in tears. Since then it has never been the same, the anguish and trauma from that moment set in slowly. It is day 73 and she has barely played it anymore, weed has ravished her island, her friends have left, pirates and others have taken over her island and still she sits in total pain of what the game has done to her. Truly devastated from the trauma she has now quit her job and now wallows everyday blaming her evil husband and how he was the root cause of it all. HELP

I have been an animal crossing fan for around 15 years and of course wanted to follow the franchise when it came to the Nintendo switch. I absolutely love how Nintendo has transformed this game from what it once was in my childhood. New horizons not only has some great new additions such as diving for sea creatures but has also kept many of the much loved characters and peaceful coastal settings that make me feel like I‚Äôm 7 again hiding under my blanket on my white DS lite on a school night. I thoroughly recommend!!

This game is just okay, because of time gating. If you bought it way after release I‚Äôd recommend putting your switch 12 days back so you can ‚Äútime travel‚Äù to catch up. Once you finish day one. Which is really quick you will then want to time travel just to unlock the game. And then you will need 30 iron nuggets which tbh takes like 5 days of rock farming. So again time travel just for that... after you have done that it is easier to slow down the amount you play a day. But because this game is time locked it becomes very boring if you do not either play very little a day (1 hour) or time travel. CONSTANTLY. It kinda removes the fun that you have to save, quit, change date, reopen game and see what is now unlocked. If they removed the time gating it would be a much better game. I will say however. This game is hard to put down now due to isolation. Even if you have other new games it is very time consuming as soon as you unlock plenty stores and Nook miles and you can try and get that 5 star rating. Then you can play it as meant to. One day at a time without time traveling. But I‚Äôd definitely recommend time traveling for about 10-14 days before you play less and do daily grinds. Definitely not worth the hype train you can wait to buy this game used or restocked. Do not pay more than 45-50¬£ for it!

This is a great game for kids of any age. I have seen a eight year old and a 25 year old play it and love it.  A better version of sims in the day. A fantastic little game that will eat up your spare time. Whether it be decorating your home, growing and tending your garden, socialising, adventuring, shopping, teraforming the landscape, crafting or interacting with the wildlife, Animal Crossing has something for everyone.The game works in real time so times of days, seasons, deliveries, and events change depending on what's happening in the real world. This creates a slower paced game and allows you as a player to take your time and let your little island grow organically with every decision you make.There are some complaining about island sharing with others on the same console but the fact is it makes the game better. Islands are sizable so there is plenty of space for everyone but most importantly this is a social game and multiple residents makes it easier to harvest and share resources which is ESSENTIAL to progression. All in all a wonderful game and highly recommended.

Great fun for all ages...Super calming music and the graphics are amazing...It‚Äôs a little slow at the start but once you‚Äôve put a few hours in, it's the same excellent AC experience :)You can get as creative as you'd like...I love that things change with the seasons, just when you think your done or what can i do next the season changes and with that comes new adventures.They have added a lot more content since the previous games you can now progress at your own pace with no pressure to do certain tasks straight away. It has all the same lovable characters and content from previous games with a lot of exciting new elements.Haven't had the mole yet... So not to sure if his still around LOL

Couldn‚Äôt have been more excited for this to be released and don‚Äôt get me wrong, it‚Äôs good but is it as good as Animal Crossing on the DS?!? In one word, no! From someone who has never played an animal crossing game, I was always conflicted as to whether I would like it. The pacing and content was always something I was worried about up until I played it.With that being said, I absolutely love it. It is amazingly unique in its concept and goal, and it succeeds massively. It is jam-packed full of fun things to with all the relaxing benefits of island life. This is game you will be playing for months. It is hard to describe in words, the game feels like many emotions and moods combined. Part open world, part exploration and crafting, part farming, part interior / exterior designing, part collect-a-thon, part city planner.  I think it has a little something for everyone.I would say it is a must-have on the switch.

To clarify the title, if you're an adult but a casual gamer/new to gaming, you may like this. But if you're a more hardcore demographic (Skyrim, Call of Duty, Red Dead Redemption, Zelda etc) or simply want an experience with any substance, you may be left disappointed.The game really doesn't have much content or purpose, it lacks direction. You move to a resort island, pay off the loan by completing tasks, and eventually get a little house you can put items in. You can also help with other little buildings or the few island residents.The problem is, the tasks you must do are mind numbing, shake trees to get apples and sticks, fish, place items etc. The from on the tiny island is quite limited and many times you cannot progress the game as it runs on the console's real clock. Meaning you must turn the game off and wait afew days. You can only make one island on one console, you can visit a friend's island but there's nothing to really do.Overall, it's a very dull game, it tries the give little direction playing on the notion you can go and be free; do what you want. But sadly doing what you want is limited, boring or requires not playing the game for a few days. I'm also personally not a fan of the curved parallax scrolling? Like Mario Galaxy, it somehow makes the space of the small island feel even smaller, a 3D camera at least would've bettered this game.For children aged 11 and under this could be an enjoyable game or way to kill time, for adults that find more complex games or control schemes difficult, this may be a more accessible experience.For anyone else, all that awaits is underwhelming disappointment.

Brilliant game for all ages - our 7 and 9 year olds and ourselves all love it.Massive down side is only being able to have one island and the first player to have played being the main player throughout - only once they have unlocked items and made decisions do the other player benefit.Despite that we all still really enjoy it, but all players should have equal capabilities and play options.There is always so much to do, discover, explore and enjoy ..... so detailed, amazing graphics - good problem solving and strategising opportunities for children as well as being great fun.

i love this game.i've played animal crossing since it's very first rendition, and not only is new horizons everything the franchise always has been, it's even more. do i wish i could sell weeds/fruits/fish and be able to pay off several mortgages in one go? yes. do i wish i was an elite trader on the turnip market? yes. do i want this game to absorb me tron style so i can live, breathe, and die on a deserted island with a racoon? please nintendo...i am 25. will i ever have a mortgage? maybe i eat too many avocados, but honestly, this one is wonderful for all ages. i change my clothes more often in animal crossing than i do in real life. is that okay? i think so.

I have never played an animal crossing game. But saw the previews and loved the look and style of the game, so I dropped my money for the pre order. It took 3 hours of me and my wife playing to be hooked. Every detail of this game is so well made and so well polished. It is incredible how addictive it becomes to catch a new fish, build a new tool or pay off some the debt on your house. This game is perfect escapism. It took me 3 hours to be hooked and love this game and I have no doubt I will still be hooked for a long time to come.

Great product

Do you like to play games for escapism? Challenge? To get a sense of completing something worthwhile, improving your status or moving on to the next chapter of a story?Then don't buy this.This game is none of these things, it's basically one enormous random number generating gambling machine.For instance - which rock will give me the coins? 1 in 6 chance of that.Which tree will give me return after planting? [insert equation] chance of that.Which island will the nook miles ticket take me to? [insert equation] chance of that.Which islander will I get when I open up some land or go to an island? [insert equation] chance of that.Which DIY recipe will I get on the beach today? Random Number Generator... RNGWhich items will be for sale in Nook's Cranny? RNGWhich clothing will be available? RNGWhich fossils will I get today? RNGWhich fish will I get from this small-size fish? RNGWhich visitor will I get today from the twat who's communicator breaks every time, to the pewdiepie-wannabe fishmonger, to the insect craved 80s punk? RNGRNG RNG RNG - getting a theme yet?Ad infinitum. It's boring, incessantly and obsessively repetitive and mind-numbing.Add in the real-time need that FORCES you to play at specific times, which effectively means you are owned and driven by this damn game, and all the fun that it could and should be is completely void, vapid and removed.I actually found it depressing, not because of the money I spent on the game, but because of the frenzy surrounding its release, and what ended up being a gambling OCD addiction machine of a game. And all of these tasks allow you to do what? Check out animals in a museum, where you can't zoom in enough, or get close enough to the creatures you worked all damn year to collect? Or place items in your house that serve basically no purpose except have a singular interaction (if you're lucky), and are behind loading screens for each room transition?In my opinion the only way worth playing this is going to be emulated and with a trainer, so you can select the things you want.I didn't realise Nintendo was in the industry of creating gamblers.

Animal Crossing for me is the best game Nintendo produced throughout all the Consoles but they still haven't got New Horizons right. I have two children aged 11 and 13 and they have to share the same island which is causing huge arguments about planting and placing objects between the two of them, for me Animal Crossing is a very personal game for the gamer to design and plan whatever they want without some other user coming along and changing it. Extremely fun game, very in-keeping with other animal crossing games BUT please beware if you are a family with multiple players using the same switch e.g. kids, couples.Gameplay allows only one save per console - which means if you are sharing a switch you are automatically locked into sharing one island and it's resources. But this is not the main issue. The first person to create their profile has the lead role and experiences the entire game in full - tutorials, recipes, unlocking new buildings etc. Any other players unfortunately are limited in what they can do and have completely different experiences. They do not get the main story and instead are locked behind the 1st player waiting for them to unlock things to progress the game.This can be a BIG problem and cause a lot of frustration - especially if you have children who are looking to each play the game, don't understand why each can do different things or even cannot play anymore as the lead player has stopped and not unlocked what is required. Seems like a cheap shot by Nintendo to encourage household to have more than one switch console and game to avoid the problem.

Bought for myself and my 11 year old daughter and we both absolutely love it. Very additive and loving designing our own little Islands (we do have our own switches as we wouldn‚Äôt be able to do that otherwise as it‚Äôs 1 island per console).

The Animal Crossing series has been running for many years, but New Horizons succeeds at making you feel like you are the Animal Crossing. You can build, destroy, and manifest anything almost anywhere, you can greet new animals to your village, you can shape the island to your own view. It is truly a hybrid of open world and simulation, and by far the perfect game for almost anyone on the switch.

This is just the game you need if you're after something cute and mindless to fill you time. It's easy going and you can just dip in and out as you please, and it's guaranteed to relax you whenever you pick it up. There's a lot of new features as well as a lot of classic Animal Crossing game mechanics, so it's perfect for both old and new fans.

While this is a highly appealing little game to construct your own world, the number of insidious psychological tricks used to force players - especially children - to play for as long as possible is really off-putting as a parent trying to monitor and educate healthy screen use (initial set up takes at least an hour before you can save to suck the user right in, you‚Äôre then landed with a ‚Äòdebt‚Äô which will clear more quickly the longer and more frequently you play etc etc). What‚Äôs more, you can only construct one island per game card - individual users on the same device/card cannot have their own islands but must only play on the one. This is once again a clear ploy to drive Nintendo sales so parents don‚Äôt have to referee children battling over sharing one island, but just buy another device or game card. Not impressed, and if my two don‚Äôt cooperate on this, they‚Äôre not getting another Switch, the game is going on eBay!

I absolutely love this game and have played it on other consoles such as the DS. When my daughter and I bought a Switch recently, I was looking forward to introducing her to the game and playing together - it is advertised as multi-player. However, what it doesn't tell you is that you can only create and save one island.  Only the person who creates and saves gets the full Animal Crossing experience. The second player (and indeed any other players) is limited in their creativity. They are not given recipes to build items, they cannot take part in rebuilding projects. In order to do this, you would need to restore the game to factory settings to start again. The only way for all players to have a full experience is for them to buy another Switch and another Animal Crossing game. Considering I've just spend ¬£50 on this, I'm feeling a bit robbed (and upset if I'm honest - this was going to be a bit of lockdown escapism for my depression). This is the first time I have ever been disappointed in Nintendo.

Its ok. And thats the best and the worst that can be said about it. Its fairly relaxing, but everything is time gated  meaning that its a "log on every day and make slow progress" game rather than one you play under your own terms.  Its more akin to a grindy mobile phone game without the micro transactions than a full priced title. I have to be honest; I find it quite dull. You run out of things to do easily because of the time gating. Your activities are not that varied (90% of your activity is collecting materials and this is hard capped daily). I frankly wish I hadnt spent the money really (especially at full retail price). However my subjective opinion isnt the retailers fault so I guess Im stuck with my purchase and my regret...

I don't know if this has reared its ugly head, however if you are planning on playing this between 1 switch and 2 people don't bother. I am sorry that I can scarcely afford 1 switch but this is ridiculous. In a nut shell, no matter if you select a different profile you have to share 1 island, you can't have separate islands. This basically means that if the game is started and that player is say for example 4 hrs in, any new player is thrown in at that point. It gets worse, the more tasks completed by any player will leave less and less for the other user, eventually meaning that all the other player can do is walk round leaving the game useless as I have found out. If there is more than 1 player another switch will be needed. I actually sent it back as me and my wife both wanted to play it but it became confusing and tedious as the game was already started by 1 of us.

There‚Äôs nothing physically wrong with the product this time (the first time I ordered it, the case came empty without a cartridge!), but as caution to people debating buying a switch *just* for ACNH. I‚Äôve found it a crushingly disappointing game so far, given how much I liked the older ones like New Leaf. People said it would get better past the grind, and over 100 hours in, I feel like the item variety has been chopped down significantly; customisation is a weaker way of varying items; and if like me you don‚Äôt have membership, it is impossible to collect all the fruits etc in the game, and therefore you can‚Äôt make all the DIY recipes you receive. I largely regret buying my switch for this game. I‚Äôm just plugging hours in to try and improve it, then realising how many hours I‚Äôve plugged in for very little gain makes me sad.

As others have pointed out, the first player to play creates their own island  and later players are subservient to them. While there are warnings that you can't change your user name or DOB, nowhere does it mention this. Daughter 1 plays at 18.00 hrs. Then daughter 2 goes to play at 19.00 hrs and finds that she is on daughter 1's island. A bit of googling shows that even buying a second game won't work as it is one island per console. There are a lot of annoyed players out there who have let a four year old have first go and then are stuck on her island.
